last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The 2nd Mongol invasion of Hungary shows how to counter them.
The Hungarians got their shit wrecked by the Mongols the first time around, but for reasons I forgot, the Mongols turned back.
When they came back, the Hungarians had heavily westernised, building an absolute fuckload of castles, buying crossbows, rely more on heavy cavalry, and generally adopting a more western style of warfare.

The Mongols no longer could win one key battle, or capture one key city to win. They couldn't raid, because people just kept everything (including livestock) in the castles, which would have to be besieged. Besieging a castle would of course cost a lot of time, and if done with smaller detachments, they would be picked apart by troops from other castles who could just crush the besieging forces with impunity.
Bypassing the castles was also not an option, because men could come out from them and ambush foragers, ruin supply lines, and just cause general mayhem. The Mongols were starved and killed almost to the man.

Ironically, this whole method of anti-nomad warfare was partially the result of Hungarians attacking western Europe when they were the steppe raiders.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Not sure how I feel about these games. I think it's fair to call them stealth games, they sell you on the fantasy of being a set of sneaky guys outwitting an overwhelming force. But they tend to play almost like a turn based game, despite the simulation still running, because it enters a steady state. If you're safe that won't change until you do something.

Playing it almost feels like chess, where you're working backwards from what you want to achieve and assessing each threatened square / guard until you see an opening.

Are there other stealth games that occupy a similar end of the spectrum? I'm interested in seeing what other takes there are on the more puzzle-like approach to this game design.
